title: 110_hr4995
content: The Middle Class Jobs Protection Act of 2008 is also known as the Reduction in Corporate Marginal Income Tax Rates. The Middle Class Jobs Protection Act of 2008, also known as the Reduction in Corporate Marginal Income Tax Rates, amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It reduces the corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 25 percent for personal service corporations. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, with specific effective dates for certain provisions. SEC. 3 of the Middle Class Jobs Protection Act of 2008 increases the limitation on expensing certain depreciable business assets. The dollar limitation for taxable years beginning in 2007 or 2010 is $125,000, and for years beginning in 2008 or 2009 is $250,000. The reduction in limitation is $500,000 for years beginning in 2007 or 2010, and $1,000,000 for years beginning in 2008 or 2009. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 of the Middle Class Jobs Protection Act of 2008 allows a 50 percent depreciation allowance for certain property acquired during 2008 and 2009. The Middle Class Jobs Protection Act of 2008 allows a 50 percent depreciation allowance for certain property acquired during 2008 and 2009. Amendments to section 168(k) of the Internal Revenue Code extend bonus depreciation deadlines to December 31, 2007 and January 1, 2010, with effective dates for property placed in service after December 31, 2007. The amendments made by this section do not apply to property covered by section 105 of the Gulf Opportunity Zone Act of 2005. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a 5-year carryback for certain net operating losses, starting in 2008 or 2009. SEC. 6 allows a 3-year carryback for certain credits. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for special rules for excess amounts in taxable years 2008 and 2009, including adjustments to the number of taxable years for certain provisions. Additionally, a provision for foreign tax credits in taxable years 2008 or 2009 is introduced. In taxable years 2008 or 2009, taxpayers can elect to substitute 'any of the three preceding taxable years' for 'the first preceding taxable year'. The amendments apply to credits in taxable years after December 31, 2007.
